content: I know you all are talking about the chimp but on the topic of animals or reptiles people shouldn't have as pets... My buddy in the Florida Wildlife Commission sent me this photo. All these goofballs in Miami get these snakes as pets. Then once they get too big, they let them loose in the Everglades. The problem is, these snakes go around killing off the protected species of wildlife out there so FWC has to go hunt them down to cut down the population. Don

content: I believe it was the owner's freind, who was attacked. Really, though, it makes no difference. Wild animals, regardless of how they are reared and trained, will always have a predisposition to revert to wild animalistic behavior. Just ask Sigfreid and Roy...... of course they blamed the lights and crowd-noise for the kitty-attacking-owner incident.

content: no i didnt..but i occasionally flew for florida wildlife and watermanagement. i would fly while the workers would go collect alligator eggs. i flew a 206 on floats, guys would get out then guys in airboats would distract the mother, they would snag the eggs and hop back in and take them in to be hatched.

content: Back around 1999, I boarded a boat south of the Florida Keys that resembled some old WW II PT boat. The guy had a wolf hybrid that looked a lot like this. title: people who keep wild animals in there homes..

content: quote: people who keep wild animals in there homes.. ...Are idiots!! How often do we hear of a python killing a baby or small child, or an alligator, tiger, leopard, or some other fangy critter wandering loose in areas no such beast belongs, endangering/hurting people, because some idiot let the thing get loose. It's all a bunch of macho-envy bullcrap - - The worst example of this kind of thing I know of personally took place in Florida in '86. An old lady not far from where we lived kept calling police to complain that a large snake had moved in under her house, and was terrorizing her and the neighbor's pets. The police considered her a "crank" and refused to honor her complaint until she called and said that the thing ate the neighbor's dog. So, to humor her, they went to see - - When an animal control officer went under her house (built on short stilts) to see, he came scrambling back out, yelling for help. It was all caught on TV. Three or four officers crawled back under - and came out with a 25 foot Python that weighed will over 200...maybe 300 pounds! I swear it head looked like a small football! Well, it was obviously a "pet" that had either got away, been kicked out, or - - ate its "owner" and moved on! People who wish to keep these things probably need a brain scan worse than an exotic pet - - Witness Siegfried and Roy...or what is left of them - - DuH!! Wandering and Wondering
quote: people who keep wild animals in there homes..

Three or four officers crawled back under - and came out with a 25 foot Python that weighed will over 200...maybe 300 pounds! I swear it head looked like a small football! Well, it was obviously a "pet" that had either got away, been kicked out, or - - ate its "owner" and moved on! People who wish to keep these things probably need a brain scan worse than an exotic pet - - Witness Siegfried and Roy...or what is left of them - - DuH!! Wandering and Wondering

".. sorry just my usual bored at work rants. cheerio! Amongst other job titles I hold a certificate for NJ Animal Control Officer. Too many states have to lax of laws that allow idiots to own animals they have no right to own. Thank goodness in NJ it is illegal to privately own a primate(any type). I was at a chemical immobilazation class & the instructor was saying Ohio is up there amongst the most lax. He had to respond to some clown who owned a lion which got loose! Call me crazy, but if an animal can look at you & think "yummy", you shouldn't own that animal.

content: I was watching "Animal Planet" the other day and they were doing a story on Miami's rescue team, "Venom 1". Some goofball up near Lakeland got bit by his pet Black Mamba snake and almost died. Now how pathetic do you have to be to need a Black Mamba to stroke your ego???? Can you imagine if the snake got out into the neighborhood after it bit him? DUH!!!! He has cobras and rattlesnakes too. He keeps them in a back barnlike building in cases. Don

Call me crazy, but if an animal can look at you & think "yummy", you shouldn't own that animal.

content: I know you all are talking about the chimp but on the topic of animals or reptiles people shouldn't have as pets... My buddy in the Florida Wildlife Commission sent me this photo. All these goofballs in Miami get these snakes as pets. Then once they get too big, they let them loose in the Everglades. The problem is, these snakes go around killing off the protected species of wildlife out there so FWC has to go hunt them down to cut down the population. Don

content: I believe it was the owner's freind, who was attacked. Really, though, it makes no difference. Wild animals, regardless of how they are reared and trained, will always have a predisposition to revert to wild animalistic behavior. Just ask Sigfreid and Roy...... of course they blamed the lights and crowd-noise for the kitty-attacking-owner incident.

content: no i didnt..but i occasionally flew for florida wildlife and watermanagement. i would fly while the workers would go collect alligator eggs. i flew a 206 on floats, guys would get out then guys in airboats would distract the mother, they would snag the eggs and hop back in and take them in to be hatched.

title: people who keep wild animals in there homes..

content: quote: people who keep wild animals in there homes.. ...Are idiots!! How often do we hear of a python killing a baby or small child, or an alligator, tiger, leopard, or some other fangy critter wandering loose in areas no such beast belongs, endangering/hurting people, because some idiot let the thing get loose. It's all a bunch of macho-envy bullcrap - - The worst example of this kind of thing I know of personally took place in Florida in '86. An old lady not far from where we lived kept calling police to complain that a large snake had moved in under her house, and was terrorizing her and the neighbor's pets. The police considered her a "crank" and refused to honor her complaint until she called and said that the thing ate the neighbor's dog. So, to humor her, they went to see - - When an animal control officer went under her house (built on short stilts) to see, he came scrambling back out, yelling for help. It was all caught on TV. Three or four officers crawled back under - and came out with a 25 foot Python that weighed will over 200...maybe 300 pounds! I swear it head looked like a small football! Well, it was obviously a "pet" that had either got away, been kicked out, or - - ate its "owner" and moved on! People who wish to keep these things probably need a brain scan worse than an exotic pet - - Witness Siegfried and Roy...or what is left of them - - DuH!! Wandering and Wondering
quote: people who keep wild animals in there homes..
